content: प्रकृतिः {%<ab>f.</ab>%} {@--1@} The natural condition or state of anything, nature, natural form (<ab>opp.</ab> विकृति which is a change or effect); प्रकृत्या यद्वक्रं <ls>Ś. 1. 9</ls>; उष्णत्वमग्न्यातपसंप्रयोगात् शैत्यं हि यत्सा प्रकृतिर्जलस्य <ls>R. 5. 54</ls>; मरणं प्रकृतिः शरीरिणां विकृतिर्जीवितमुच्यते बुधैः <ls>R. 8. 87</ls>; <ls>U. 7. 19</ls>; अपेहि रे अत्रभवान् प्रकृतिमापन्नः <ls>Ś. 2</ls> ‘has resumed his wonted nature’; प्रकृतिमापट् or प्रतिपद् or प्रकृतौ स्था ‘to come to one's senses’, ‘regain one's consciousness’. {@--2@} Natural disposition, temper, temperament, nature, constitution; प्रकृतिः खलु सा महीयसः सहते नान्यसमुन्नतिं यया <ls>Ki. 2. 21</ls>; कथं गत एव आत्मनः प्रकृतिं <ls>Ś. 7</ls> ‘natural character’; so प्रकृतिकृपण, प्रकृतिसिद्ध see below. {@--3@} Make, form, figure; महानुभावप्रकृतिः <ls>Māl. 1.</ls> {@--4@} Extraction, descent; गोपालप्रकृतिरार्यकोस्मि <ls>Mk. 7.</ls> {@--5@} Origin, source, original or material cause, the material of which anything is made; प्रकृतिश्चोपादानकारणं च ब्रह्याभ्युपगंतव्यं <ls>Ś. B.</ls> (see the full discussion on <ls>Br. Sūt. I. 4. 23</ls>); यामाहुः सर्वभूतप्रकृतिरिति <ls>Ś. 1. 1.</ls> {@--6@} (In Sān. <ab>phil.</ab>) Nature (as distinguished from पुरुष,) the original source of the material world, consisting of the three essential qualities सत्त्व, रजस् and तमस्. {@--7@} (In <ab>gram.</ab>) The radical or crude form of a word to which caseterminations and other affixes are applied {@--8@} A model, pattern, standard, (especially in ritualistic works). {@--9@} A woman. {@--10@} The personified will of the Supreme Spirit in the creation (identified with माया or illusion); <ls>Bg. 9. 10.</ls> {@--11@} The male or female organ of generation. {@--12@} A mother. {@--13@} (In arith.) A co-efficient, or multiplier. {@--14@} (In anatomy) Temperament of the humours. {@--15@} An animal. {@--16@} An artisan. {@--17@} The Supreme Being. --<ab>pl.</ab> {@--1@} A king's ministers, the body of ministers or counsellors, ministry; <ls>R. 12. 12</ls>; <ls>Pt. 1. 48</ls>, <ls n="Pt. 1.">301.</ls> {@--2@} The subjects (of a king); प्रवर्ततां प्रकृतिहिताय पार्थिवः <ls>Ś. 7. 35</ls>; नृपतिः प्रकृतीरवेक्षितुं <ls>R. 8. 18</ls>, <ls n="R. 8.">10.</ls> {@--3@} The constituent elements of the state ( सप्तांगानि), {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} 1. the king; 2. the minister; 3. the allies; 4. treasure; 5. army; 6. territory; 7. fortresses &c.; and the corporations of citizens (which is sometimes added to the 7); स्वाम्यमात्यसुहृत्कोशराष्ट्रदुर्गबलानि च <ls>Ak.</ls> {@--4@} The various sovereigns to be considered in case of war; (for full explanation see <ls>Kull.</ls> on <ls>Ms. 7. 155</ls> and <ls n="Ms. 7.">157</ls>). {@--5@} The eight primary elements out of which everything else is evolved according to the Sānkhyas; see <ls>Sāṅ. K. 3.</ls> {@--6@} The five primary elements of creations ( पंचमहाभूतानि); {%<ab>i. e.</ab>%} पृथ्वी, अप्, तेजस्, वायु, and आकाश.
